Risk Management Plan Executive Summary
Atlantic Energy, Inc. Chesapeake Terminal


1. Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies

Constructed in 1973, the Atlantic Energy, Inc. Chesapeake Terminal provides a vital energy service to homeowners, commercial businesses, and industry.  The facility has an excellent safety record, and its employees are key players in achieving that safety record.

Atlantic Energy is committed to safe and reliable operation for the protection of its employees, the community, and the environment.  Atlantic Energy is proud of its 27 year operating record, during which there has never been an incident that resulted in any off-site impacts to neighboring industries, residents or the community at large. This record has been achieved through consistent attention and total dedication by management and staff to safe operating practices and preventive maintenance.  Atlantic Energy has constantly made new investments in the latest technology in operating and maintaining the facility.  These practices form the backbone of Atlantic Energy's dedication to keeping the facility and its community safe.


2. Description of the source and regulated substances handled.

The Atlantic Energy Terminal in Chesapeake, VA imports and stores fully refrigerated liquid propane (also called liquefied petroleum gas or LPG) at -45 deg F.  The terminal processes this product by heating it to +40 deg F for shipment to its customers by truck and rail.  Ethyl mercaptan, an odorizing agent, is added to the LPG being distributed from the terminal.  Both propane and ethyl mercaptan are regulated flammable substances.  The terminal has no RMP listed toxic chemicals in threshold quantities.


3. Hazard Assessment

The Risk Management Program (RMP) rule requires companies to develop release scenarios that estimate the potential community impact from an accidental release. These scenarios are intended to be useful for emergency planning in the event of an accident. Two ty

pes of scenario are required by the EPA. The worst-case scenario is the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance. It assumes meteorological conditions that would result in the greatest impact. The alternative release scenario allows industries to develop a more realistic scenario for emergency planning.

The worst case scenario at the Atlantic Energy terminal is a large release of propane that would have off-site effects. The alternative release scenario is a limited release of propane from a loading hose failure that would have off-site effects. The release prevention program described in Section 4 is designed to minimize the chance of an accidental release.


4. Release Prevention Program

The terminal was designed and built in accordance with provisions of the following three recognized standards for LPG facilities:

*  NFPA 58, Standard for the Storage and Handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases, (National Fire Protection Association).

*  API 2510, Design and Construction of Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Installations, (American Petroleum Institute).

*  API 620, Design and Construction of Large, Welded, Low-Pressure Storage Tanks, (American Petroleum Institute).

The plant is attended by at least two operators at all times.  They log field operating data at four-hour intervals and monitor plant equipment using the following monitoring and control systems:  Indoor operating areas of the plant are monitored by combustible vapor detectors to quickly detect leaks.

The main control panel, located in the central control room, displays pressures, temperatures, valve positions, and flow rates and provides for remote operation and manual or automatic shutdown of valves and equipment.

Written policies and procedures for safe operation are contained in the following Atlantic Energy manuals:

*  "Operations Manual and Emergency Manual," covering normal startup, operation, and shutdown of marine unloading systems and equipment.

*  "Commonwealth Propane, In

c. Field Safety and Operational Handbook," covering safe handling of the product.  It covers safe work practices and permitting requirements for such activities as hot work, electrical work, confined space and vessel entry, excavation, and other hazardous activities.  Plant security and visitor policies are covered.

* "Conoco, Inc. NG & GP Process Safety Managment Program," covering policies and procedures for PSM program elements.


5. Five Year Accident History

In the five-year reporting period, there were no release of propane or ethyl mercaptan that resulted in injuries, deaths, property damage, evacuations, sheltering in place, or environmental damage either on site or off-site.


6. Emergency Action Plan

Emergency planning, preparedness, and action are covered in the "Operations Manual and Emergency Manual," which details responses by facility employees, the Chesapeake Fire Department, and the US Coast Guard.  All new employees are given initial training in emergency action procedures.  Employees receive refresher training on an ongoing basis.


7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The facility has been in operation since 1973.  Safety reviews have been undertaken periodically since that time.  Many recommendations arising from these reviews have been implemented through equipment and procedural changes.

A process hazard analysis (PHA) of the entire facility was completed in October 1997.  All issues identified during that review were dealt with by spring of 1998.  The most recent review was a PHA completed in October 1999.  Issues from that review will be resolved prior to October 2000.  Atlantic Energy will update the PHA periodically and will deal promptly with any recommendations.
